awd_titl_txt: Emotional Distress and Maternal Health Vulnerability
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

Experiences of maternal stress are important mediators of the relationship between mental and reproductive health and vary among women facing different stressors. Identifying the precise factors that affect experiences of diverse mothers and how these, in turn, impact vulnerability, is thus critical to informing efforts aimed at alleviating maternal and infant health disparities. This project examines the experiences of pregnancy among foreign-born immigrant women and native-born women who face a diversity of stressors and supports during pregnancy. The research includes presentations to disseminate results to community stakeholders and a white paper to disseminate results to policymakers. The project will be conducted through a Hispanic Serving Institution, offering research training for undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups.

Specifically, this research seeks to understand how women internalize immigration-related stress and in what ways women's experiences shape biological markers of stress. The research builds on the theoretically influential, but often poorly operationalized, concept of embodiment by examining the specific pathways that link experiences of stress and individual histories to demonstrable biological markers of stress. These issues will be investigated using a multi-phased design that includes analysis of survey data, self-reported experiences of stress, biological stress data, health records, and in-depth interviews. The research offers an important window and a holistic perspective on concerns and the differential experiences of immigrants and native-born women in the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project explored women’s emotional experiences of pregnancy, birth, and the postpartum period in the midst of a series of longstanding and ongoing crises in the US-Mexico border region. El Paso, Texas has long been a symbolic battleground in the enactment of policies that threaten the well-being of individuals, families, and communities. The racist undertones of anti-immigrant sentiment have contributed to various forms of violence in the community, including the 2019 mass shooting at a Walmart that was the deadliest attack on Latinos in US history. As the community continued to mourn this tragedy, the COVID-19 pandemic unleashed yet another set of economic, social, and public health catastrophes that were disproportionately felt within the border region. These circumstances produced conditions of despair as women sought to have and raise children with dignity.

            The research included collecting survey data, health records, and cortisol samples (a biomarker of stress) from a sample of 176 Latinas utilizing publicly funded prenatal care and recruited from a clinical context, enabling a comparison of self-reported experiences of stress to stress-sensitive health outcomes and a physiological biomarker of stress. Sixty of these women participated in at least one in-depth interview; 14 participated in multiple follow-up interviews during the first year postpartum. Participants included both US-born citizens and foreign-born women, and their experiences show the wide-ranging familial and community effects of immigration and border policies. Women’s narratives and health records reveal the ways social stressors, especially those tied to immigration and border policies, exacerbated by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, contributed to vulnerabilities for adverse maternal health outcomes. These adverse outcomes are often poorly documented in local and state-level maternal health monitoring systems. For example, nearly 25% of the women in our sample developed preeclampsia, compared to a national prevalence rate of 5-10%. Since Texas hospitals are not required to report preeclampsia data, there has been little attention to the gravity of this high prevalence rate locally, despite the fact that it is a leading contributing factor to maternal mortality and morbidity. This research also documented a high prevalence of gestational diabetes, postpartum hemorrhage, and emotional distress (that often went unregistered as possible depression).

            Theoretically, our data shows the significance of attending to local biologies, or the ways that the local context contributes to health vulnerabilities and the experience of ill health. In particular, the COVID-19 pandemic and immigration and border policies were central to shaping the vulnerabilities to and experience of adverse maternal health outcomes among the women who participated in the research.

            Data analysis and development of research products related to this project remain ongoing. To date, the work has resulted in the the book Birth in Times of Despair (NYU Press, 2024) and five article manuscripts that are in various stages of development. Additional research products include two graduate student theses, nine conference presentations, participation in one conference roundtable, eight poster presentations at student research symposia, a student roundtable at a university-wide conference, a podcast interview, a video interview, three invited guest lectures, and a research brief circulated to local policymakers.

            This project resulted in mentored research experiences for ten undergraduate students and four graduate students. All of these students are from groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields. Some of the student positions were funded by this grant. However, the project also created opportunities for students being funded through other university-sponsored programs to gain research experiences. In addition to participating in data collection and analysis, these students had opportunities for professional development through presenting at conferences and contributing to article manuscripts.

            To disseminate research findings to the community, this project included the development of a Maternal Health Community Advisory Board. Board members included representatives of the offices of local policymakers, employees of community organizations, and health providers who serve the population of interest. The group met biannually. The office of our local US representative also met with our research team on multiple occasions. When research findings showed that women thought they were losing Medicaid coverage during the Public Health Emergency, which would have been a violation of federal guidelines, we submitted a research brief to members of the advisory board. This resulted in a state representative opening inquiry with Texas Health and Human Services to ensure that women maintained Medicaid coverage in accordance with federal guidelines. 

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2024
Modified by: Carina Heckert
